THE STORY - This was my 8th skydive—my final jump for the Skydive AFF license. My instructor looked at me and asked, “How do you want to exit?” Now here’s the thing—there’s this running joke (and lowkey belief) among skydivers that your 8th jump defines what kind of skydiver you’ll become. It’s the jump where things start to click, fear starts to fade, and instinct begins to take over. Until that point, I had never done a front roll exit. I knew it was bold for a license jump, and I didn’t want to mess it up. I was nervous—I really wanted to pass. But deep down, I also wanted to look fear in the eye and remind myself: I was born for this. I hesitated. My instructor could see it. So he smiled and said, “We’ll decide at the door.” And as I stood there, with the wind howling and my heart thumping through my chest, I looked at him, nodded, and said, “Front roll.” I went for it. No looking back. And in that moment, I realized— It’s not the sky that limits you. It’s your mind. Break that barrier, and the world opens up.

Looking for an off-the-beaten-path escape? 🏝️ takes us to the San Blas Islands, a hidden Caribbean paradise off Panama’s coast! 🇵🇦✨ This untouched archipelago has 365 islands, but only 49 are inhabited by the Guna people, who’ve preserved their land and culture for generations. 💚 Getting here is an adventure! Arrive by boat from Panama City, then hop between islands in traditional canoes, lounge on pristine beaches, and feast on fresh lobster. ⛵🦞🌊 With no mass tourism, limited WiFi, and glowing bioluminescent waters at night, this is the ultimate digital detox. Dholkal <ORG> 🙏🏻 . Video by and <ORG> This unique idol of Lord <ORG>a is located on Mountain Dholkal in Chhattisgarh’s Dantewada at the height of around 3000 feet. The idol, brilliantly carved out of stone, was the victim of the systematic vandalism and destruction of Hindu icons and objects of worship recently, when it was vandalised by Maoists in 2017. But the Maoists could not kill the divinity of the idol and the mountaintop, and devotees complete a difficult trek to climb 3000 feet on foot to reach the idol to have a darshan and worship it. The idol was carved and installed in the 11th century and was worshipped regularly. But with time it went out of people’s memory and got covered by trees, and remained hidden for many years until it was rediscovered by the British in 1943 before opening the Bailadila mines. The idol is around 3 feet tall and weighs more than 500 kgs. The <ORG> idol, carved from a solid piece of granite, is perched on its beautiful circular perch amid the deep, impenetrable woods of Bastar in Chhattisgarh’s Dantewada region. However, post-independence, the idol got vanished from public memory again until the year 2012 when a journalist marched on a trek into the dense forest leading to the Dholkal mountain peak. This rediscovery created a sensation, so much so that the Dholkal <ORG> temple became a popular destination for pilgrims, trekkers, and history lovers. . <ORG> , TAG or use HASTAG to feature .

ICELAND - The Land of <ORG>s 🩵 Foss is the Icelandic name for <ORG>, so you’ll find the word affixed to every local name for it. And they’re PURE…magic. Back in 2014, my dad visited Iceland on a work trip, well before <ORG> music video and our very own ‘Gerua’ catapulted it to mass social media popularity. Even my dad’s ’dad-photos’ made our jaws drop. He sent us a grainy <ORG> photo of Skógafoss and my brother and I were stumped. Only a few months later, our family found itself in Iceland to celebrate my dad’s 60th birthday. That’s when my romance with Iceland, and dare I say, traveling itself began. I’ve always felt that Iceland’s waterfalls aren’t just a visual delight- calling them just that would be reducing the sheer power, wonder and magic they hold. These waterfalls will activate all your senses on overdrive. Summer or winter, they come as a full package with the landscapes that adorn them. Lush green or snow white, with unique layers and patterns, flowing with such force you’re stunned and arrested on the spot. Their spray will get your skin, the thunderous roars will ring in your ears long after you’ve left them behind, the sweet smell of earth and water will tickle your nose buds and smell like nature at its purest, oh and the feeling…the pumping of your heart, the widest O on your lips, the tears just waiting to spill out of joy and overwhelming wonder.. There’s probably THOUSANDS of them all around this tiny, precious country. But some of them have names and are more popular than the others, and also more accessible. I’ve name-tagged the ones and I made it to last year. The ones we missed that were on our list?- Hengifoss, Svartifoss (I hiked to see it back in 2015!), Háifoss and Klifbrekkufossar. Let me know your favourite ones too if I’ve missed any? PS: Please note, not all are accessible during winter. And even in the summer, please check road.is and Vedur app for road conditions.

Step into the vibrant world of Ger Mela (Kavant Mela)—a dazzling tribal festival in Gujarat where tradition meets high-energy celebrations! From breathtaking folk dances and mesmerizing body art to rhythmic beats that echo through the air, this festival is a riot of colors, culture, and pure joy. It’s not just an event; it’s an experience of a lifetime! Would you love to witness this tribal extravaganza? 🎉✨

Every year after Holi, Jesawada comes alive with the vibrant “Godh Gadheda no Melo”! 🎉 Young men try to climb a 20-25 feet tall wooden pole (usually trunk of a tree) to grab a pot of jaggery (Godh), while women circle below, singing, dancing, and beating them with sticks like ‘donkeys’ (Gadheda)! 🐴💥 It’s a test of strength, spirit, and fun rooted in ancient Swayamvara traditions. Only the bravest reach the top and win the prize (and bragging rights)! 😉✨ Back in the days, the young man who wins could marry his favorite bride from the crowd of girls - replicating the ancient tradition of Swayamvara✨

Stepping into Ger Mela (Kavant Mela) felt like diving into a whirlwind of colors, energy, and raw tradition! The beats of tribal drums, the hypnotic dances, and the sheer joy in the air made this festival an unforgettable experience. From speaking with locals to immersing myself in the celebrations, this was a journey into Gujarat’s rich cultural heart. Have you ever witnessed a festival this vibrant? 🎉

At Ger Mela (Kavant Mela) in Gujarat, I spoke to fellow travelers and participants to find out what draws them to this vibrant tribal festival. Their answers? Stories of tradition, devotion, and an unbreakable bond with their roots! From mesmerizing tribal dances to the sheer energy of the celebration, this festival is a living, breathing cultural treasure. Have you experienced such raw and authentic festivities before? ✨🎉

Kids under 18, close ye eyes! 🫣 Turns out Morning Wood’s a thing in the jungle too, eh? BUT on a more serious note, here are some facts- 🦁 A lioness may mate up to a 100 times (?!?!) a day with an average interval of 17 minutes each mating lasting for an average of not more than 21 seconds. This frequency is needed because lion breeding has a low fertility rate in general 🦁 Male cats have spines on their little big guys down there, to cause slight trauma to the lioness upon withdrawal. The resulting pain is what triggers ovulation. OUCH! 🦁 The Gestation period is between 100-180 days, and once the cubs come, the lioness doesn’t mate again for 2 years or so I can’t BELIEVE I casually witnessed this on my sunrise safari at Kruger national park, just hours before my flight out of South Africa! My parents and fam ditched me because they were tired (all 5 of them!), but I refused to cancel so my safari guide and I had a grand old time in the wee hours of the morning. We even spotted a leopard about 100 metres in, but my camera couldn’t capture it cos it was too far for my lens :( Even this is something I wish I could’ve filmed on my <ORG>, but it was all happening too quick and my guide was like, your phone’s ready just go before they stop ! 😆 But man! What a send off, <ORG>! I’ll be back, I just know it 💚

WE SAW THEM! 😭🐋 I hope you enjoy watching this simple, raw, real build up to THE moment. It’s still only a fraction of what we experienced as we caught Four flights and waited DAYS to catch a sighting of these elusive giants on their migration towards Antarctica. On the final day of the group trip, we finally saw two of them. We spent close to 2 hours to let them get comfortable with the only two boats (ours) out at the Banda Sea, until they began to come up in a pattern we observed and learnt from our excellent team of guides. And finally, towards the end, the <ORG> said we could jump in, only 3-4 at a time. And we did. And I first saw it all alone when I jumped in without fins and a snorkel (long story!) I was exhausted but euphoric. I don’t think I processed it at all. That day was reserved for feeling Compersion in the joy of all of my fellow divers 🥹 But for the next 3 days, these elusive <ORG> put up a show I will forever hold close to my heart. Everyday, we saw them EVERYDAY since. Casually passing by our dive resort, en route a dive site 10 minutes from our resort, during a surface interval…just, anywhere and everywhere. I even began to spot them first everyday, once I learnt how to from our skilled crew. Nature is magic. To bestow upon us these gentle beings who are the LARGEST animals to exist on our Planet. I don’t have the words, they’re disjointed at best. You can only imagine how difficult life is in winters where the temperatures fall below -70 degrees Celsius . Even simple daily tasks like bathing, using the washroom, cooking, travelling to work are big problems because of freezing temperatures, inaccessibility and scarcity. It was mind blowing to know that despite these extreme conditions, this place (Oymyakon in the Sakha Republic, Siberia) has the most number of people that have lived above the age of 100!! I feel when people have so much to do to just survive in such places, they have lesser time to stress about other mindless things. They’re mostly busy just finishing daily tasks. Somehow maybe that is relieving in a way and maybe that’s why they’re happier? 🥲What do you think??

1 million of Stalin’s Gulag prisoners died while constructing the R504 Kolyma Highway in Siberia. The road was nicknamed the “Road of Bones” because of the suffering of the prisoners who built it. The road was built to deliver prisoners to the gold mines and prison camps of Kolyma - an area rich in natural resources. As the road is built on permafrost, the popular rumor spread that burying people into the fabric of the road was more practical than digging new holes to bury the bodies of the dead. Untold numbers died constructing the highway across the frozen ground. Prisoners said that there was one body for each tree cut down to clear the forest. The average lifespan of prisoners here was 6 months. The road now snakes through the wilderness of the Russian Far East. It passes through vistas of harsh beauty dotted with frozen, unmarked graves. The road now has rapidly vanishing traces of labor camps. It’s deemed the world’s most dangerous road because people frequently die while traversing this road. And that’s why you’re legally obliged to stop and check if you see a car broken down and help. We drove on this road for 18 hours to reach the Oymyakon village - deemed the coldest place and also the Pole of Cold. The drive was hauntingly beautiful but eerie. I was like “Yup gotta do this!” And ended up doing it THREE times!! 🤣 The first time I was scared and didn’t know what it would feel like, the second time I got a little used to it and the third time is when I could actually enjoy it! 🤓 Ice baths are popular cuz they’re supposed to be good for your health and people do swim in these rivers.
